description:
Refers to takeout (in Hong Kong, the British *takeaway* is the more common term) and delivery food. Now more than ever, Chinese restaurants advertise takeout and delivery options, and Asian grocery stores often have takeout dim sum.

**Characters**

[外](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A4%96) means *outside*, and [賣](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E8%B3%A3) means *sell* (also the second character in [siu mai](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shumai) 燒賣.

There are other ways to specify takeout depending on context and region, for example 拎走 (līng jáu) is literally *carry to go*, 帶走 (daai jáu) is *bring to go*, and 打包 (dá bāau, same 包 as all the [bao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baozi)) generally means “to wrap” or “to pack” (literally “tie up in a bag”) and is how you'd ask to bag up leftovers.

[外賣](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E5%A4%96%E8%B3%A3) means *takeout*, and [杯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%9D%AF) is *cup* (or *glass* or *mug*).

[杯](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E6%9D%AF) is also the [measure word](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measure_word) for drinks. For example, [一](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E4%B8%80) means *one*, so to order a glass of water, ask for 一杯水 (yāt būi séui in Cantonese, yī bēi shuǐ in Mandarin), *one cup of water*.
